result.heading: SOUNDS OF A GREGORIAN FUNERAL CHANT

direction.raw_text: . COUNTRYSIDE  DAY TITLE SEQUENCE The faces of several young children are presented in CLOSEUP, as they walk TOWARD US across a ploughed field. On the SOUND TRACK, the haunting SOUNDS OF A GREGORIAN FUNERAL CHANT. The CAMERA PANS UP to the faces of older brothers and sisters, then to parents and grandparents. These are not familiar faces, but faces from another age, strong and open. All are dressed in the distinctive clothing of the Amish.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . COUNTRY LANE  DAY Through the last traces of early morning mist another group of black-clad figures make their way down a lane.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . COUNTRY LANE  DAY An Amish buggy, black and highwheeled, stark against the landscape, appears, a spirited chestnut in the traces. Framed in the glass window of the narrow buggy is the stern figure of an Amish man in black topcoat and flatbrimmed hat, his bonneted wife in muted colors, the face of a boy, attired like his father, peering out. The horse's breath smokes on the frosty air, the buggy CREAKS on its springs, and there's the rhythmic CLIP-CLOP OF HOOVES on the pavement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two Amish buggies reach a crossroads, join a procession of three others. They disappear as the lane wends through a leafless thicket of hickory.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... now the procession numbers almost a dozen buggies... it is headed toward a distant farmhouse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where literally dozens of carriages are parked. The horses have been taken from the traces, removed to the shelter of the barn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the black clad mourners begin to move into the house (women and children presumably first).
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The coffin has the upper half open. We see that the corpse has been dressed in white linen, a piece of white linen partially covering the bearded face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LAPP FARMHOUSE Partitions have been removed, making the central rooms of the farmhouse a spacious hall. The place is packed, a hundred- fifty or more Amish, all sitting in absolute silence on rows of wooden benches. A wooden coffin rests on a bench in the f.g., and near it the close relatives of the deceased occupy a special Place.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A young woman of perhaps twenty-seven. Her face is pale and drawn. In happier circumstances, although there haven't been too many of late in Rachel's life, we would see a robust, sensual woman of full figure, spirit and intelligence. Eight-year-old SAMUEL LAPP flits next to his mother; he would appear stunned, possibly not entirely comprehending events. And the patriarch, ELI LAPP; his stubborn, weathered  yet not unkind  features grief-stricken.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Their faces...

dialogue.raw_text: ...a brother has been called home. God has spoken through the death of our neighbor, Jacob Lapp...

dialogue.raw_text: ...husband of Rachel, father to Samuel, son of Eli. (and) His chair is empty, his bed is empty, his voice will be heard no more. He was needed in our presence, but God needs such men, too. That one should be taken so suddenly. Treat sorrow. Still, we would not wish him back. Rather we should prepare ourselves to follow him.

Rachel looks up from the back-breaking labor as several figures approach it's Daniel Hochstetler and two of his brothers. Without a word they fall in beside Eli and Rachel and take up various tasks associated with the work in hand. Daniel works close beside Rachel.

direction.raw_text: As Samuel enters. It's a long row of sinks, urinals, and stalls... Samuel stops before one of the urinals  a long, trough-like affair with water drizzling down the rear porcelain panel. It's set a little high for Samuel, and it is making GLUGGING FLUSHING NOISES that are, at least, intimidating. Samuel stares for a moment, then turns, looks toward the stalls, stoops to see which are empty.

direction.raw_text: As Samuel proceeds along the row of door, finally selects a stall near the end. He enters. As he does so, a heavily bearded youth in a dirty sweatshirt enters. With some urgency, he removes small notebook from his pocket and places it behind a paper towel dispenser. Suddenly he glances up. Two other men have entered the men's room; one is a large BLACK MAN in a three-piece suit under an expensive, overcoat. His PARTNER is a Caucasian in designer jeans, half boots and a short leather jacket. They advance on the young man with unmistakable menace. The young man whirls in terror; his two assailants lunge for him... a savage, wordless struggle ensues in the close confines of the lavatory.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HAPPY VALLEY  NIGHT Sixty black faces stare as the police enter. A hush falls on the group. Book and Carter spot their man at the bar and move up either side of him. They've moved carefully to this point... no mistakes. From the back, the black man they've approached certainly looks like he could be the man who did the killing of Zenovitch. And, as Book and Carter make their move...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HAPPY VALLEY  NIGHT As Book and Carter explode through the door of the bar, violently propelling Coalmine along with them. Now we see Coalmine is not the killer. As Book and Carter escort Coalmine out of the bar a police squad car pulls up, its headlights shining into Book's car. An alarmed Rachel holds Samuel close as Book forces Coalmine's face down next to the car window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A cop pulls out a flashlight, begins to play the beam over Coalmine's face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Crazy as Rasputin on speed and booze, Coalmine glares at Samuel inside the car: Samuel, white-faced, finally shakes his head in the negative. Coalmine tries to twist free of Book's grip. Book snaps, and slams Coalmine's skull into the window edge, finally crushing his face up against the front window. His face takes on a grotesque shape against the glass. Carter restrains his partner and Book cools down. Coalmine is led stumbling away by the uniformed police. This sudden show of violence has horrified and angered Rachel, and she glares at Book as he gets back in the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Book sighs, starts the engine and moves off.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Put some light on him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (continuing; to Samuel) Look at him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: John Book, you listen to me! I will have no further part in this, nor will my son! As God stands between us!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . HOTEL  PHILADELPHIA  NIGHT Book pulls up outside a hotel entrance as a uniformed DOORMAN moves to open the rear door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CAR  NIGHT Rachel and Sam recoil as the Doorman opens the door. He is puzzled by the sight of the reluctant guests.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Book and Carter exchange a glance.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Ma'am?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No! We do not stay in hotels.

direction.raw_text: . / INT. FRONT DOOR, SUBURBAN HOUSE  PHILADELPHIA NIGHT An attractive woman in her early thirties in robe and slippers stares in disbelief as Rachel and Sam file into the house. This is ELAINE, Book's sister. She stops Book as he tries to follow Rachel inside.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: How could you do this to me tonight? I told you I had company
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sorry. It's important.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As she glances in a doorway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ELAINE'S KITCHEN It's a shambles, with dirty supper dishes piled sink, the table littered with empty beer cans.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As she hustles Samuel along.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Book frowns:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Elaine looks like she's going to blow again, then decides it's pointless.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Where's Timmy and Buck?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Upstairs, asleep. Where'd you think?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've got a man here and the kids are upstairs?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's none of your goddamn business! So keep your goddamn holier-than- thou mouth shut! (and) Anyway, they like Fred.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh sure, Fred.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who are these orphans, anyway?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Samuel is asleep in one twin bed in a tiny, cluttered room. Rachel, in a plain nightgown, is preparing to climb into the other one. Off screen we hear a DOOR CLOSE, presumably Book leaving. A beat, then Elaine opens the door and looks in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She nods and goes. Rachel crosses to Samuel, sits on the bed. Samuel looks up at her bleakly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She puts her hand on his forehead, closes his eyes. she frowns, and...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Everything okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, thank you very much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a beat) John said you're Amish.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (blankly) Oh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't want to stay here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They are English. They don't understand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wish dawdie was with us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (swallows) I know. Sleep now, Liebchen.

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . ELAINE'S HOUSE  DAY Elaine's house is situated on the corner of a row of terraces, which stretch into the distance on both sides of the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Samuel comes out of the guest room in his night-shirt, turns up the hall and opens the door to the bathroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But it's not the bathroom; it's Elaine's bedroom. She and FRED are tangled in the sheets, furiously making love. Elaine gasps, Fred manages to grunt.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Wrong door, kid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As Samuel quickly shuts the door. A straight-faced beat; then, barely suppressing a giggle, he hurries on...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Rachel appears in the living room entry. Samuel is sitting on the floor with two boys of about his own age, watching television. They're eating cold cereal out of a box.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: TV SCREEN Some artless Saturday morning cartoon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As she frowns, watching her son and the other two staring hypnotically. And...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's later in the morning now, as Elaine, a bit blearily, appears in the entryway, stares in groggy disbelief.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: KIDS Her oldest boy and Samuel are busily washing the windows while her youngest is pushing a carpet sweeper. The TV is off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As she stares.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rachel is standing in the middle of the now immaculate kitchen finishing a brisk mop of the floor. The coffee is perking. Elaine appears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rachel turns cheerily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She takes a seat at the table, still shaking her head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rachel means no harm by this, but Elaine's eyes begin to storm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rachel's smile fades at Elaine's trembling outburst:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Abruptly Elaine rises and snatches the mop from Rachel's hands. She mops furiously as she Continues:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She finishes the floor, hurls the mop aside with a CLATTER:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rachel is speechless, Elaine is on the point of bursting into tears. At which point Fred appears at the entry in his undershirt, taking in the sparkling kitchen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not a politic observation on Fred's part.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And, bursting into tears, she flees the kitchen. Fred stares after her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Unperturbed, he crosses to the counter and the coffee pot, letting his eyes take in Rachel's full figure.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (mutters) Jesus...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good morning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (helplessly) You didn't have to...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wanted to. you were kind to take us in last night. (and) Anyway, I needed something to do. I was so angry with your brother. He's so... agaanisish!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Aganishish? Yeah, that sounds like John.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just a minute. I'll pour you some coffee.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're not carrying a bullwhip... how'd you manage to put my kids to work?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiles) I made it a contest... the one who does best gets his cereal back first. (and) Children like to help... they only need to be kept after a little bit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, is that so? (and) No offense, lady, but I'm not so sure I like the idea of your coming in here and turning the place upside down!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please, I didn't mean...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know exactly what you meant! Listen, maybe I'm not a world-class housefrau, but maybe I don't have time to polish the goddamn china and keep after the kids! (and) It's none of your business, but I don't happen to have a man around here full time. So I sell cosmetics in a goddamn drugstore and sometimes I can even pay the rent on time! So maybe I'm not Mary Poppins, but maybe I don't need to have it jammed down my throat like this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There is that clean enough for you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jesus, Elaine... Somebody die and leave you a broom?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (blurts) Go to hell, Fred!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's bugging her?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As Rachel comes in with Elaine's coffee, closes the door behind her. Elaine is lying across the bed, sobbing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She takes a seat next to the bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: After a moment, Elaine starts to pull herself together:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She takes the cup, sips the coffee. Rachel smiles at a private thought.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rachel smiles.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I brought your coffee.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry. I didn't mean it that way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's okay. (and) Look, I shouldn't have blown my top. It's like... somehow... I've let everything get away from me. And you sort of made me face it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's so funny?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fred. The way he looked when you screamed at him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (disparing) God, Fred...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: At home you'd never hear a woman scream at a man that way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No? Why not?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You just wouldn't. It's not the Amish way. (then) But I think it would have done me good if I could have screamed at your brother last night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Listen, I don't know what's going on or how you got mixed up with him, but don't you let that self-righteous son of a bitch push you around, okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Book glances irritably at Rachel:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Book gives her a look:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rachel glares at him and the ride continues on that chilly note for a beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Samuel has been glancing at Book; finally he says something to his mother in German. Book gives her an inquiring look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Book says nothing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She doesn't bother to explain; Book settles even deeper into his funk as Samuel glares at him with hostility.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Now what's the problem?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The problem is I don't happen to think my son should be spending all his time with a man who carried a gun under his coat and goes around whacking people.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Whacking?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (firmly) Yes. And I also want to leave this city.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Believe me, I'm trying to get this over with as fast as I can. But Samuel will probably have to come back and testify.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We do not go into your courts.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: People who don't go into our courts when they're told to sometimes go directly into our jail.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, I'm genuinely sorry...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (snaps) No you're not (off his look) You're glad, because now you've got a witness. (and) I heard the other police talking last night. (and) They don't seem to like you very much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They kid a lot.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (glances at him) I would not be too sure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He says you look very tired. I thought the same thing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But not a good tired.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's a 'good' tired. Tired is tired.

direction.raw_text: .Q.  DAY Samuel sits with Book at a desk, Rachel just behind. They are looking at a police line-up of known black drug-dealers. Samuel shakes his head  another negative. Book winks, slyly reaches into a pocket, produces a yellow gumball. He surreptitiously shows it to Samuel, gives him an inquiring look. It's a peace offering. Samuel grins, nods imperceptibly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Book rolls the gumball down the table to Samuel. But just as Samuel is about to cover it with his hand, Rachel reaches over and plucks it off the table. She shakes her head at Samuel.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to Rachel) Just wanted to see if you were on your toes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CITY PARK  DAY Book, Sam and Rachel sit on a park bench eating a lunch of hot dogs heaped with kraut. Book watches with amusement as Samuel wolfs down his lunch. Rachel eyes him a beat. then:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Book gives her a look:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Book is staring at her. Rachel nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just then Samuel belches with huge satisfaction, drawing looks from Book and a couple of passersby. Rachel smiles proudly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Your sister said you don't have a family?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She thinks you should get married and have children of your own. Instead of trying to be a father to hers. Except she thinks you're afraid of the responsibility.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh? Anything else?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh yes. She thinks you like policing because you think you're right about everything. And you're the only one who can do anything. And that when you drink a lot of beer you say things like none of the other police would know a crook from a... um... bag of elbows.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think that's what she said.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good appetite.
dialogue.name: dialogue

KAMAN, eyes Book a little suspiciously internal affairs officers are not greeted warmly by the working policemen in any department.

Samuel has drifted out of the office and is idling amid the bustle of the squadroom. He crosses to a glass case which holds a collection of plaques and framed newspaper accounts which denote instances of outstanding duty and achievement.

direction.raw_text: NEWSPAPER ACCOUNT Enlarged, prominently displayed. The headline reads: "Division Chief McElroy Honored For Youth Project". Accompanying the item is a large sidebar mug-shot of McElroy  clearly the black man who murdered the young cop in the train station men's room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He stares, transfixed. A long beat, then Book, lowering himself to one knee next to Samuel, ENTERS FRAME. He's watching Samuel, knowing from the boy's expression that they've found their man. Samuel slowly raises his hand to point at the photograph. Book gently takes the boy's small hand in his, concealing the accusation from watchful eyes. He smiles gently at the boy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rachel is curled tight in her corner of the front seat holding Samuel close. Book glances at her:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rachel shakes her head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She says nothing. Another beat, then:
direction.name: direction

direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Why don't you arrest that man? Are you protecting him because policeman?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (snaps) Listen, I'm the cop that polices the police. I'm not in the business of protecting crooked cops. (eases up) I'll make an arrest when I know everybody involved.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But why would they murder...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Because  somehow  they knew I was getting close. (and) Look, it's narcotics... They make dope out of chemicals... they sell it on the street for millions of dollars. They'll do anything. (and) And they can get away with it because they're cops.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (beat, then) I'm afraid. I'm afraid for Samuel. I want to go home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'll be safe. You don't have to worry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, they're thinking as long as they keep the killer out of Samuel's way, we can't make an I.D. There's no way they can know Samuel saw that photograph, so he's safe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I mean it. You will be safe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh yes! Of Course. Why shouldn't we feel safe in a city where the police are so busy killing each other!
dialogue.name: dialogue

She knows Book and is surprised and delighted to see him. In the background daughter KATHY is visible. Schaeffer himself appears and Book is welcomed inside.

(excited, explaining the thing eagerly) He salts it away somewhere... he knows the stuff is potent, but the street chemists haven't figured out how to process it. But they do now. dialogue.name: dialogue

PARKING LOT  PHILADELPHIA  NIGHT Book slams the front door of his car, checks it for being locked, glances at a roiled newspaper in his hand (the sports section of the Inquirer), starts across the parking lot toward his apartment, walking as he keeps glancing down at the sports section. He comes to a sort of crosswalk, stops, reads, starts to take a step... and looks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: McElroy, smiling nicely, starting across toward him from the other side of the parking lot crosswalk
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Freezing, eyes widening. Utterly surprised and caught.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Still smiling, he brings up his right hand out of a shopping bag (which he appeared to be carrying)  letting the shopping bag fall away as he does so  revealing a five-inch barrel Smith and Wesson .357 blue finish revolver with a silencer. Without hesitating, coming right on, still smiling, he FIRES once.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Already starting to leap away to one side, he is hit, driven into a half-turn. He clutches at the wound, as:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Coming right on, FIRING again... the pistol's report a WHOOSHING, like the opening of a bottle of cheap champagne. And McElroy still smiling as:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hit... a grazing near-miss this time, but enough to send Book down hard and grasping.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lowering the pistol alongside his leg, as two MEN, barely taking notice of anything, cross with their backs to Book toward McElroy. He smiles at them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Down, muttering CURSES.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As McElroy walks past Book, drops the pistol to the pavement, keeps on going... and is gone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: in pain, beginning to try to crawl crab-like. And we HEAR  from the agonized recesses of Book's Dream.

direction.raw_text: As the lights of an oncoming car  going very slowly, on its way to a parking space  sweep over him and we HEAR it come to a sudden, squealing stop. Book is already trying to get to his feet... now succeeds, lurching into a swaying stance, using an adjacent car for support. OFF SCREEN we HEAR a car door slam, and footsteps hurrying in our direction, accompanied by excited voices. Book HEARS, turns to face the oncomers,

direction.raw_text: As Book lapses back into sleep. Rachel hasn't removed her hand from his chest. Abruptly she does so. She finds herself wondering about this man lying before her, so suddenly a part of her life. She notices details; bruises, scars, the knuckles are hard, grazed, a tattoo on one shoulder. While lost in this reverie, the delirious Philadelphia policeman begins to mutter. Incoherently at first, then the words take shape  swear words; curses; fuck this and that; shit; etc. Rachel rises abruptly, her cheeks coloring, as the barrage of language pours from his mouth. She beats a hasty retreat closing the door swiftly behind her.

location: LAPP FARM LANCASTER COUNTY NIGHT REESTABLISHING,

direction.raw_text: As Samuel comes in with a fresh bedpan. Book is lying asleep on the bed. Samuel puts the bedpan down, checks to make sure Book is indeed asleep, then quietly crosses to the foot of the bed and opens the clothes chest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Book's big .38 revolver lies holstered atop his folded clothes. Fascinated, Samuel picks it up, admiring the heavy burled pistol grips. Unable to resist, he starts to remove the weapon from the holster, then pauses to steal a look. OFF SCREEN...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His eyes are open and watching Samuel icily, which gives the boy something of a jolt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mutely, Samuel hands Book the pistol from arm's length. He looks on as Book takes the pistol out of the holster, shoots the boy another look, then snaps open the cylinder and shakes out the heavy, copper-jacketed bullets into his palm. He snaps the cylinder closed again, then nods to Samuel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The boy edges closer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Book smiles. Then he gives the boy a playful, John Wayne- tough guy wink as he cocks and uncorks the pistol, demonstrating the action. He finally hands it over to Samuel, butt first.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The boy tries to imitate Book's one-handed expertise, but his hands are too small. Book smiles. Samuel finally manages to get the thing cocked, using two hands, and Book reaches over to guide the muzzle away so that it's not pointed at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Samuel levels the pistol at the door and, just as he snaps the trigger, Rachel enters, pulls up short in some dismay to find her son has a gun pointed at her. Samuel blanches and Book winces, knowing there's heavy weather ahead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Samuel quickly hands the pistol back to Book, who holsters it:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Samuel quickly exits, and Rachel angrily advances on Book.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Book looks at her thoughtfully. Rachel softens a bit:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hands her the holstered gun and the loose bullets.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A beat, then Rachel, takes the pistol and starts to go. Book stops her:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rachel glances back at him, smiles and nods. And...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Give me that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You ever handle a pistol like this, Samuel?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (swallows) No pistol. Ever.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tell you what  I'm going to let you handle this one. But only if you promise not to say anything to your momma. I've got a feeling she wouldn't understand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grins) Okay, Mr. Book.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Call me John.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't want to point that at people you just started calling by their first name.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (snaps) Samuel!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wait for me downstairs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: John Book, I would appreciate it if, during the time you are with us, you would have as little to do with Samuel as possible.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nobody meant any harm. The boy was curious. I unloaded the gun -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's not the gun. Don't you understand... It's you. What you stand for. (and) That is not for Samuel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please, it has nothing to do with you personally.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Put it up someplace Samuel can't get it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Friends?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . KITCHEN  LAPP FARMHOUSE  NIGHT Book's holstered gun and bullets at center table. Eli sits on one side, a chastened Samuel on the other. Rachel looks on from the b.g. Eli knows that this is as important a dialogue as he will ever have with his grandson: at issue is one of the central pillars of the Amish way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Samuel stares at it, not meeting his grandfather's eyes. Eli leans forward, extends his hands ceremonially.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A beat, then Samuel musters some defiance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now he meets Eli's eyes:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eli expels a deep sigh; then:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He breaks off, bows his head for a moment. Then he fixes the boy with a stern eye and, driving he heel of his palm firmly into the tabletop with enormous intensity:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His intensity tinged with righteous anger, he is hugely impressive.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The gun  that gun of the hand  is for the taking of human life. Would you kill another man? Eh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What you take into your hands, you take into your heart.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I would only kill a bad man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Only a bad man. I see. And you know these bad men on sight? You are able to look into their hearts and see this badness?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can see what they do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have seen it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And having seen, you would become one of them? (intent... gesturing) Don't you see...? The hand leads the arm leads the shoulder leads the head... leads the heart. The one goes into the other into the other into the other... And you have changed, and gone amongst them...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: "Wherefore come out from among them and be ye separate, saith the Lord!"
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (indicating pistol; continuing from Corinthians 6:17) "And touch not the unclean thing!"
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . WASHHOUSE  NEAR KITCHEN  NIGHT Book stands near the door to the kitchen, and has heard most or all of Eli's words. He turns, and painfully makes his way into the washhouse, moving quietly, hoping no one will come out from the kitchen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BARN  LAPP FARM  DAY Samuel harnesses up the family mare, and backs her into the traces of the buggy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BOOK'S BEDROOM  DAY Book stands at the window in a worn robe. Below, through the window, we can see Samuel and Eli in the barnyard. A beat, then Book crosses impatiently back to his bed, sits down, picks up a dog-earred copy of The American Dairyman. There's a stack of well-thumbed farm magazines and copies of The Budget (the Amish newspaper) on the bedside table. There's a knock. Rachel enters carrying a pile of clothing. She smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She passes the clothes to Book.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She continues, cheerfully.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rachel's face clouds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rachel turns to leave when Book calls her back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She turns to look at him. It's the first time he's used her name.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She smiles and leaves.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Enjoying your reading?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Very interesting. I'm learning a lot about manure. (eyes the clothing) What's that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your shirt and jacket are still stained with blood. I have them soaking.You can wear these.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your husband's?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. It's good that someone can have the use of them. Besides, in your clothes you'd stand out to strangers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I should tell you these do not have buttons. (shows him) See? Hooks and eyes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Something wrong with buttons?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Buttons are Hochmut.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hochmut?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Vain. Proud. Such a person is Hochmutsnarr. He is not plain.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nodding) Anything against zippers?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (almost blushing) You make fun of me. Like the tourists. Driving by all the time. Some even come into the yard. Very rude. They seem to think we are quaint.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Quaint? Can't imagine why.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where's the nearest telephone?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Telephone? The Gunthers across the valley. They're Mennonite. They have cars and refrigerators and telephones in the houses even.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. I'd want a public phone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well... the store at Saltzburg... (then briskly) But you won't be going to Saltzburg for a while.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm going this morning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But Stoltzfus said...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cutting in) I know what he said.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can go with Eli. He's taking Samuel to school. But you'll have to hurry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Rachel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . FARMHOUSE  DAY Eli calls impatiently from the buggy. Samuel sits beside him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hurry up now, John Book!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . KITCHEN  DAY Rachel washing dishes turns on hearing Book enter. She laughs out loud at the sight of him in his Amish gear, and rightly so  the pants are highwater, the hat low-rise, the jacket ill-fitting. Book looks self-conscious, even a little sheepish. Outside another SHOUT from Eli.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Book looks embarrassed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The smile fades from Rachel's face as she reaches up into a cupboard. She passes the gun in its holster to Book. He fastens it about him. The contradiction of an "Armed Amishman" increases the awkwardness between them. Book turns his back to her and checks the weapon. He turns back to her smiling in an odd way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She takes them out of a disused coffee jar, passes them to Book.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You'd better go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My... eh... gun?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The... bullets?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh. The bullets.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (attempting a joke) Not much good without them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . BUGGY  COUNTRY ROAD  DAY Samuel sits between Eli and Book. Both men stare straight ahead. Eli looks particularly stern. It's pretty clear he doesn't like this Englishman wearing the clothes of his faith.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . AMISH ONE-TEACHER-SCHOOL  DAY With awave Samuel runs into the schoolyard to join his friends. A teacher begins ringing a bell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Book on the telephone waiting for his call to be answered. He looks about him  several Amish and Dithers mingle in the shop. Book-has gotten a coke from a machine, seems a bit self- conscious shout it sips at it surreptitiously... A voice comes on the line; it's that of Book's partner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A beat as Book considers that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Book allows himself a small smile, regarding his Amish image reflected in the window of the store.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hangs up. A beat, then he stares toward the door of the store.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Johnny! Where the hell have you been?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Never mind. I'm coming in to take care of business. How hot am I?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (low, urgent) Too hot. Don't do it. Don't come in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm coming.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Listen, Johnny, don't do anything stupid. You couldn't get within a mile of Schaeffer right now. So stay put... Stay in touch  I'll let you know when maybe it makes sense.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (edgily) You hear me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (finally) I hear you. I'll stay in touch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's more like it. (and) Where are you at, anyway?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where I'm at is maybe 1890.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (uncomprehending) Say again?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Make that 1790.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . BARN  DAY Book works on his car. The battery has gone flat and he's trying to charge it up by running wires to a battery mounted under the front seat of the Lapp buggy. Eli stands at the barn door staring at him, again the disapproving look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Book is genuinely apologetic.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: If you are well enough to do that thing, you can do work for me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure, I'm sorry. Hope you don't mind me plugging in to your battery. Mine's dead... How can I help? What can I do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe milking.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (eyes Eli) Milking?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Cows. You know, cows?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've seen pictures.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good, you start tomorrow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . BOOK'S ROOM  LAPP FARM  NIGHT Where Book lies asleep. A beat, then Eli comes in carrying a lamp. He pauses a moment to peer at the sleeping figure with undisguised anticipation. Then he gives him a jarring thump:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Book comes groggily awake as Eli exits. He gropes for his watch.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (briskly) Veck oufl. Time for milking.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: WATCHFACE It reads 4:30 a.m.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As he stares at it in disbelief.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the milk herd of half dozen or so cows ambles in with Samuel prodding them along, headed for the milking stalls. Book looks on in the lamplight, nonplused.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where he's pitching hay into the cow's feed-troughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where the old man is showing Book how to milk a cow by hand. We see Rachel watching from the milkhouse door (steam from scalding milk cans rising behind her).
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Book gives him a look, takes over the milking stool. The cow shoots him a rather skeptical look over her shoulder. Book bends to his task.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eli unexpectedly finds this hilarious, cackles, gives Book a comradely, man-of-the-world thump on the shoulder that jars him. Then he moves off. Book bends to his task, and...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Good, firm twist and pull, eh? (and) Right. Now you try it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Didn't you hear me, Book? Pull! You never had your hands on a teat before?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grimly) Not one this big.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: RACHEL Grinning, giggling, covering her mouth with one hand. As he pours a pail full of milk into a large, stainless steel milk can.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the milk herd is released back into the pasture. Book crosses into the f.g., stares OFF SCREEN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: HORIZON And dawnfire etching the hilltops. The BELLHOUSE behind the house, the sun reflecting from the heavy bell beneath its small roof.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Something in him can't help but respond to the beauty. A beat, then he blows on his hands, rubs them briskly together against the morning chill, and turns back to the barn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LAPP FARMHOUSE  DAY It is later in the morning. Rachel comes out onto the porch, tosses a pan of dirty dishwater off onto the grass, looks toward the barn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: THE BARN Eli and Book standing in one of the open doorways, looking in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE BARN ANGLE FAVORING Luke, one of Eli's team of fine mules as Samuel opens the stall gate. The beast is skittish, obviously afflicted with something of a behavioral problem. But he allows Samuel to lead him out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Samuel brings Luke out. Eli is now harnessing the other mule of the team to a large manure-spreader. But as Luke nears Book, his eyes widen and he shies, almost hauling Samuel off his feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Book moves to Samuel's aid; a gesture which proves a serious mistake. Luke erupts into a SCREAMING, bucking cyclone. Samuel who no doubt has been here before  dives nimbly for cover as a flying hoof nearly takes Book's head off. Then Eli hustles into the fray, pushing Book aside as he BELLOWS belligerently in German at the rearing animal. Finally he gives Luke a swat upside the head that seems, somehow, to have the effect of quieting the beast instantly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (alarmed) Careful, son
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Samuel gives the shaken Book a look:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eli leads the pacified mule back to the traces, grunting at Book.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: That's Luke. He doesn't like strangers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (still shaken) You don't say.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have to teach you mules, too, I guess.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . FIELD NEAR FARMHOUSE  DAY Book collects the pieces of the birdhouse which his car knocked down the day of his attempted departure. He pauses as a figure approaches. We recognize Daniel Hochstetler, Rachel's would-be suitor. He heads for Book with an outgoing smile and outstretched hand. Here's a likable man who likes people.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Book is not particularly amused.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hochstetler gives Book a powerful clap on the shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hochstetler heads for the house. Book stares after him with some interest.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Good morning. Book, is it? You are the Yankee they talk about?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought I was the English.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: English, Yankee. It's the same. My name is Daniel. Daniel Hochstetler. (sizes up his clothes) You look plain, Book. (grinning) Very plain.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I came to see Rachel Lapp.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Try the house.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (genially) You bet. you take care of yourself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As Rachel emerges from the house to greet him. She also catches sight of Book and she pauses, a shadow of confusion crossing her expression for an instant. And Hochstetler doesn't miss it either. Then she gives her suitor a genuine smile of welcome.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Book, having gathered up the pieces of the bird house, is headed toward the outbuildings, passing by hog pens. He glances toward the house:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: THE BACK PORCH Where Rachel and Hochstetler are sitting in a porch swing, sharing a pitcher of lemonade.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thoughtful... He glances at the hog pen as a huge sow SQUEALS and angrily noses her young ones away from the trough so she can feed.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Pigs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CARPENTRY SHOP, LAPP FARM  DAY Book works on repairing the broken birdhouse when Rachel enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He uses a drawknife on a piece of 2x4, with some obvious expertise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rachel smiles. Book crosses to a workbench and selects another tool.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She turns, starts to go. Then turns back, eyeing his makeshift garb:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stifling a smile, she goes. HOLD on Book a beat, then...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Eli is a fine carpenter. Best in the district. He and his father built the big house themselves forty years ago.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh? (and) What happened to Hochstetler?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We had some lemonade and he left.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A real fireball.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know carpentry?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I did some carpentry summers when I was going to school.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What else can you do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (really annoyed) I can whack people. I'm hell at whacking.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Whacking is not of much use on a farm.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now hold on. There's a lot of people who think being a cop is a legitimate job.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry. I'm sure it is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tonight I'll let out those trousers for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Eli is seated at the head of the table, Book opposite Samuel and Rachel. The table is piled high with an incredible amount of food. Eli eyes Book cagily, waves his fork at him:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Book swallows that one. With difficulty. Rachel intervenes:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Book can't refuse the challenge.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Eat up, Book. What's the matter with your appetite?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Guess I'm not used to so much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (snorts) Not used to hard work. That's what makes an appetite.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Eli, John is a carpenter. (conciliatory afterthought) As well as being a fine policeman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Eh? Well then, maybe he can go to Zook's barn-raising, eh? See how good a carpenter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But... You may not be well enough.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll drink some more of Stoltzfus' tea.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . / INT. BARN  NIGHT As Rachel, lamp in hand, walks up to the barn. She looks in to find Book tinkering with the battery hookup to the Lapp buggy. He glances up as she enters:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As she sets her lamp down near the one he's using.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another beat as Rachel watches him... Book, checking out the battery power, hits the radio  and suddenly from the Twentieth Century comes the sound of one of its major inventions  rock and roll. It fills the barn, but Book turns up the volume a click more even and, eyeing Rachel, starts moving with the beat. It's his culture, coming through loud and clear, as incongruous as it all might seem with the tough Philly cop decked out in Amish. Rachel can't help but laugh... Sensing her response, Book sweeps her up and they boogie in the lamplight, Rachel alternately protesting and laughing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rachel, confused, protests:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But she doesn't really want to. Book grins:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And it goes on... Rachel alternately protesting and laughing.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hi...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (beat) When will you be going?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not long... A few days.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You like it... Don't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No... You just stop
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (mock alarm) Next thing you know you'll be off drinking beer and racing motorcycles.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: THE BARN DOOR As Eli suddenly appears. He glowers for an instant, thunderstruck, then BELLOWS:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Rachel!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As Book and Rachel's dancing comes to a sudden halt. Both turn, look at Eli. Rachel regards him level-eyed, without discernible alarm. Book, looking a bit sheepish, goes over, turns off the radio, as:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Book hesitates, then starts to say something:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But he gets such a look from Eli that he turns, goes out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rachel is annoyed  also touched, no doubt, by the old man's plea  but irked by his condescending tone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And shaken  but proud and erect  she turns and walks out.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (in the dialect) What is this? This Myusick?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's not her fault. I
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (in the dialect) How can this be? How can you do such a thing? Is this plain? Is this the ordnung?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have done nothing against the ordnung.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (in the dialect) Eh? Nothing? Rachel, you bring this man to our house. With his gun of the hand. You bring fear to this house. Fear of English with guns coming after. You bring blood and whispers of more blood. Now English music... and you are dancing to English music! And you call this nothing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have committed no sin.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (in English) No sin? Maybe. Not yet. But, Rachel, it does not look... (tone softening... in the dialect) Don't you know there has been talk? Talk about you, not him. Talk about going to the Bishop. About having you... shunned!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That is idle talk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (in English, pleading) Do not make light of it, Rachel. They can do it... quick! Like that! And then... then I can not sit at table with you. I can not take a thing from your hand. I... I can not go with you to meeting! (the old man almost breaks down as, in the dialect) Rachel, good Rachel, you must not go too far! Dear child!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am not a child.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (suddenly stern again) You are acting like one!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I will be the judge of that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (fierce as a prophet) No! They will be the judge of that! And so will I... if you shame me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (blinking a tear now, but meeting his gaze) You shame yourself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . SCHAEFFER'S OFFICE  NIGHT Carter sits, Schaeffer prowls... slowly, letting silences grow before he strikes again with another softly-snarled question or statement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schaeffer snaps around, glares at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schaeffer stops, stands in front of Carter, takes a deep breath... suddenly smiles. And is abruptly (as he is capable of being) the man of charm and gentlemanly reason. He even CHUCKLES as he begins:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schaeffer CHUCKLES again, looks hopefully again at Carter. Carter looks back, stony-eyed. Schaeffer makes another abrupt shift in form... but still speaks softly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You know where he is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wrong.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'd lie to protect him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cool) Probably.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You admit you're lying?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shakes head) I admit I don't know where he is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're the first one he'll contact.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sighing) He's got my number.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's funny. I know he's hiding somewhere with the Amish, I know it. (a quick glance at Carter) Can you imagine John Book at a prayer meeting? Our John Book?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Either you're a member of the club or you aren't, Elton. (he nods his head, as) Tell me what you know...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What I know, Paul, is... (nodding his head) He's going to take you out...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . LAPP FARM  LANCASTER COUNTY  DAY As Book pauses by the barn door, glances over his shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: BUGGY With trace horse harnessed... Samuel and Eli loading provisions into the buggy, standing down by the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . / EXT. BARN As he goes into the barn. Book approaches Luke's stall warily... and as he does so the temperamental mule, reacting to form, starts to skitter, his hooves CRACKING against the walls of the stall. Book flinches. Book starts to talk gently to the animal:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then, summoning his resolve, he carefully opens the stall gate.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: All right, you nasty son of a bitch, we're going to be friends whether you like it or not.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As Luke eyes him balefully, Book reaches into his pocket, brings out some lumps of sugar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Finally, keeping a mistrustful eye on Book, Luke condescends to eat. Book nods with satisfaction.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: See... Sugar. You like sugar, don't you for Christ's sake?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Rachel has entered the barn, is watching Book with a puzzled expression.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Book turns, grins with some pride of accomplishment!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just then Luke skitters impatiently... Book gives him a nervous look; one last tentative pat as Luke eyes him skeptically, then closes the stall gate and turns to go:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And we...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (surprised) Well...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Won him over just like that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I see. (and) But I hope you have a lot of sugar. (then, going) Eli is ready to go to Zook's.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Later.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . ZOOK FARM  LANCASTER COUNTY  DAY BIG SHOT... it's early morning as the Amish buggies are arriving at the Zook farm for a barn-raising. In the b.g. we can see big stacks of lumber all around the construction site where a couple of dozen men have begun raising the main supports on the already laid foundation. Elsewhere, long tables have been set up and women are spreading them with cloths, setting out big tanks of hot coffee and cold lemonade for the men,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Eli, Book, Rachel and Samuel step down, Book eyes the construction site.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He goes. Book glances around as even more buggies arrive and more workmen and their families climb out. Eli appears with Hochstetler in tow. Hochstetler's broad face breaks into a grin:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pumps Book's hand with his usual vigor, smiling a greeting and pleasantry to Rachel. She looks on, amused. Hochstetler gives Rachel a look, and we realize that his showing up just now to appropriate Book was no happenstance. And Book realizes it as well.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With that he throws a huge arm around Book's shoulder and ushers him away. Rachel calls after them:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Wait here 'til I find a gang you can work with.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Book! Good to see you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Eli says you're a carpenter, Book.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's been a while.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No matter. Come with me. We can always use a good carpenter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good luck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As they move off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hochstetler nods with satisfaction:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Your hole is healed, then?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (gives him a look) Pretty much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good. Then you can go home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As the morning progresses: ...Book and Hochstetler sawing and augering out heavy timbers on big sawhorses. There's an unmistakable atmosphere of competition between the two men, which doesn't go entirely unnoticed by the half-dozen or so other young men on the gang. ...or, indeed, by Rachel; in fact, she seems  without leaning on it too heavily  to be measuring the two men as the morning progresses, and she occasionally passes within proximity of them. ...Eli and a couple of other elders prowling the job with sheaves of hand-drawn sketches under their arms, supervising the construction. All around them the structure is rising with remarkable rapidity. ...Rachel, where she's helping the women set out the huge noon meal. Other women are sitting on benches in the b.g., knitting or doing quiltwork. ...Samuel, where he's banging away with a hammer, with a group of boys his own age. Elsewhere we see little girls "botching" (a hand-clapping game played to German rhymes). ...The very elderly; sitting on the grass or in wheelchairs in the sunlight, looking on  the old men kibitzing in German, the women gossiping. Until...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of the barn-raising with the noon sun high overhead... at least a hundred and fifty men are swarming over and about the barn framework... ...some aid the rafters, some hauling lumber to the job, others sawing, hammering, drilling, joining, planing and what-all... so many that the barn seems almost to be rearing up before our very eyes. And there isn't a power tool in sight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Rachel crosses near the benches... we can see other women eyeing her, whispering among themselves, some tittering. Rachel ignores them. She joins the stoutly amiable Mrs. Yoder from the funeral sequence earlier. The older woman is emptying a big pan of fried chicken into serving platters. She smiles, obviously liking Rachel.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . YODER Everyone has an idea about you and the English.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All of them charitable, I'm sure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . YODER Hardly any of them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: THE ROOFBEAM Book and Hochstetler astride the roofbeam studs, holding them together prior to nailing them to the roof-beam. They are, therefore, crotch to the mast and facing one another, way out at the far end of the roof. Suddenly, as Hochstetler raises his hammer, the studs start to part, threatening to de-ball the both of them. Hochstetler drops his hammer, grabs both sides of the roof with incredible brute strength, and, literally, pulls it back together. Book stares at Hochstetler with nothing short of awe. Hochstetler, straining and grinning, looks to Book:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And he does nail it while Hochstetler, grinning and holding, looks on.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Nail it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The barn is done, the workmen climbing down from the rafters. It's late afternoon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hesitates. His face is pale and covered with sweat. The exertion of the day has taken its toll. He's in danger of fainting and is some forty feet above the ground. But he's determined it won't happen, determined that he won't fall, nor will he humiliate himself by calling for help. Hochstetler guesses the situation. He moves beside Book, claps an arm about him, says nothing, doesn't even look at Book. From below, someone TELLS them to hurry up. Hochstetler shouts:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The moment passes for Book, and he's okay. Hochstetler removes his supporting arm. Book looks him in the eye, nods his appreciation almost imperceptibly. Hochstetler wants no thanks, and Book knows it. Hochstetler gives him a resounding SLAP on the back, and starts climbing down. Book follows.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We admire our work!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . ZOOK FARM  LANCASTER COUNTY  EVENING The gathering has congregated to hear Bishop Tschantz offer up a blessing on the new barn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NING the faces as they listen to the heavy German words rolling out over the still evening air. Book stands a little to one side of the Amish. The prayers he cannot share with them. Rachel is aware of this, feels something of his emotion. She looks toward him, then she too closes her eyes and drifts away from him, into the soothing prayer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LAPP FARM  NIGHT Book stands outside, listening to the NIGHT SOUNDS. He turns, walks up toward the porch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PORCH  TARP FARMHOUSE  NIGHT Book takes a seat in a chair, SIGHS, looks toward the night sky. There is a SOUND, but it's a moment before he turns his eyes toward the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: THE DOOR Samuel standing there in his nightshirt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Book leans forward in his chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The boy hesitates, holds for a time, then suddenly darts across to Book, wraps his arms around him, hugs him tightly... then breaks away, turns and runs hack into the house, leaving the door open behind him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Sam...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...I want to say a thing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sitting up) What's that, Sam?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: BOOK Looking after the boy, genuinely moved. After a moment, he speaks softly:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: After another moment, he gets up, moves to close the door that Samuel has left open behind him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Same to you, Sam.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: BOOK From the lighted/shadowed area outside the door. He comes to the door, starts to close it, then hesitates, looks into see where the light is coming from. He looks down the corridor. The light is obviously coming from the kitchen. He speaks softly:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No answer. Book steps inside, pulls the door shut behind him, moves down-the corridor toward the kitchen.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Sam?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . LAPP WASHHOUSE  NIGHT Where Rachel, dressed only in a plain cotton camisole, is pouring a pail of steaming water into a tub. She replaces the pail on the stove, turns and slips out of her camisole. Naked, she folds the garment across the back of a chair. Then she pauses, containing a startled intake of breath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: FRYING PAN The gleaming bottom of a large copper skillet hanging over the stove with other cookware, we can see Book's image reflected there, framed in the kitchen doorway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rachel hesitates for a moment  and in that moment she makes a choice. Slowly she turns, to face him, without shame, meeting his eyes. And for a moment she attempts something: a look, a flash of eve... a lovely, heartbreakingly innocent effort to become, for an instant, a woman of Book's world.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As he stands in the doorway, willing himself to leave, unable to make it happen. And suddenly the moment has passed. Rachel lowers her eyes, picks up the camisole, covers herself with it without putting it on, looks away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: to him, and...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: HEN YARD Where Rachel is scattering feed to the chickens. A beat, then Book approaches from behind her. A moment, as she senses his presence. Book watches as Rachel begins to gather the eggs, placing them in the fold of her apron. When he speaks, he speaks softly, and she pauses in her work.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She goes very still, but keeps her back to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She lowers her head slightly, but remains turned away from him. Book continues to stare at her.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Last night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If... we'd made love, then, I couldn't leave.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . RURAL ROAD  LANCASTER COUNTY  DAY The Lapp carriage on a winding lane.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rachel is driving, Book sitting next to her. Samuel is in the back, looking out the rear window and not paying any attention to the adults. A beat, then a large produce truck roars past them. It's all Book can do to keep from flinching. Rachel stares straight ahead. Book glances at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rachel says nothing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now Rachel can't help but smile. She looks at him. And...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe I ought to learn to drive this thing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (beat) Pick myself up another useful skill.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . ANGLE We can see the Lapp buggy approaching a rural intersection, another buggy approaching at right angles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Rachel eyes the other buggy through the windshield.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Samuel checks out the buggy.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Samuel, who is that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It looks like Hochstetler's mare.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . ANGLE As the Lapp buggy passes the intersection and the Hochstetler buggy swings in behind them. Then the Hochstetler buggy, coming on at a faster clip, starts to pass the Lapp buggy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Rachel waves at the occupants of the other buggy; Daniel returns her greeting:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rachel gives him a look, and... gives the reins a flick the race is on.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (teasing her) Uh oh, they're leaving us behind.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Hochstetler has a couple of older folk on board, together with his young sister  at first they're not aware of the race, until Daniel can contain his excitement no longer and gives his horse a couple of whoops. The buggies are neck and neck, and the older people are not protesting loudly. It's all Book can do to refrain from grabbing the reins off Rachel, but she's something of a horsewoman and finally she gains the edge and pulls ahead of Hochstetler, to the cheers of Samuel and Book.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SALZBURGSTORE  DAY It's a Saturday afternoon in the tourist season, and they're everywhere  taking shots of anything Amish. There's a ROWDY YOUNG ELEMENT amongst them who are making their presence fast, and generally making a nuisance of themselves. Book and Rachel get out of the buggy. Samuel stays inside; the crowds make him nervous. A huge tourist bus billowing smoke pulls up nearby. Rachel enters the store, but before Book can follow he's stopped by a TOURIST LADY with an instamatic camera... She waggles the camera at him...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Tourist Lady stares at him in stunned disbelief, her grin frozen on her face. Then she begins to scuttle back from whence she came.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Could I... ah, you know?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling) Lady, if you take my picture, I'll rip your brassiere off and strangle you with it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Rachel is browsing among the stocked shelves in the company of a young Amish woman, Ellie Beiler. Rachel is carrying Ellie's tiny baby, and the infant is getting as much attention as the shopping. Book is standing at a wall pay phone in the b.g. We TIGHTEN to him, and...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A beat, then we hear the FILTERED VOICE of the Philadelphia Police Department switchboard:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Book hangs up. His breathing is thrown out by the shock of the news and he takes a couple of deep breaths to regain control. He hesitates, unsure of his next move. He makes to move away, then he turns back, finds more coins and dials a second number.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Lieutenant Elton Carter, please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you a member of the family?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What? I'm a friend of his.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry. Last night Sergeant Carter was killed in the line of duty...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . HALLWAY, SCHAEFFER'S HOME  DAY Schaeffer's wife answers the phone; she is momentarily shocked. She calls for her husband, then makes polite conversation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul Schaeffer appears, slightly irritated at being called away from the Saturday afternoon game.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . SCHAEFFER How are you, John?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . SCHAEFFER (covering mouthpiece) John Book!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll take it in the study.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . STUDY / STORE  DAY Schaeffer takes the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We HEAR the click of the other phone,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Book hangs up the phone and the dead CLICK registers on Schaeffer. Book has gripped the phone so tightly that it takes a second to unclench his fist. Then it takes something else to resist his first impulse, which is to smash out at something... Training. Get it under control. Deal rationally with the situation. He straightens his jacket, wipes the sweat/tears from his eyes, turns and walks stiffly out of the Saltzburg General Store.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You can hang up, dear.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You made a mistake, Paul. You shouldn't have taken Elton out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (beat) How bad did Mac get you? We figured pretty bad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm fine. I'm going to live a long time. That's what I called to tell you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quickly) Johnny BOOK You might want to pass it along to Mac.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (urgently) Listen to me, Johnny. Come in! You're out there all alone... We're getting close... real close... Maybe if you listen to me for a minute we can work something out so you can come in BOOK I've already got something worked out. (and) Be seeing you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . BUGGY  MAIN STREET  SALTZBURG  DAY Book, as Rachel eyes him. She has noticed his changed mood, but doesn't ask about it. He stares straight ahead, oblivious to the surroundings of the street, now crawling with tourists and traffic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NARROW SIDE STREET  SALTZBURG  DAY The buggy turns into the side street. Some hundred yards ahead another buggy is stopped in the middle of the road several youths gathered about it. A pickup truck is stopped, facing the buggy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LAPP BUGGY  DAY As Rachel approaches the scene, slowing down and finally stopping. Rachel is at first puzzled, then makes a small face, looks at Book. Rachel puts a restraining hand on Book's arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She senses him about to get out, grips his arm tightly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Book shakes free, gets out and slowly walks toward the...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Do nothing. This happens from time to time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's not our way, John. We'll have nothing to do with violence! John!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . HOCHSTETLER'S BUGGY  DAY Hochstetler and his family sit, impassive, ignoring various jeers and taunts from the English lads  various jokes about them being dirty etc. One jabs an ice cream cone into Hochstetler's forehead, which leaves a curious white circle on his forehead. Another fools about with the horse causing it to shy. A third notices the slow, sure, approach of John Book.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Book stops, his path blocked by the third youth. The youth flicks off Book's hat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hochstetler calls from his buggy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The youth momentarily unsure  something about Book's tone of voice. The youth does pick up the hat, crumples it, stamps on it, and puts it back at a crazy angle on Book's head. A pause, then Book explodes. The kid never knew what hit him or where it came from, he hits the road surface already unconscious. A second youth grabs Book from behind. A mistake. Book is smashing into him, spatters of blood from his nose flying in all directions. He's hitting too hard, too often. It's Schaeffer he's hitting. Hochstetler is pulling him away, Rachel is there too. A crowd is gathering, but as suddenly as it began it's over. Book shakes Hochstetler off him, straightens his hat, and in a kind of daze, begins walking past the scene in the direction of the Lapp farm. The youths are picking up their wounded, helping them back to their truck, aided by none other than Hochstetler. An OLD LOCAL addresses Rachel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A second man calls from the pickup.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But Rachel is already steering past the scene and following the by now distant figure of John Book.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Here comes another one!
dialogue.name: dialogue
